Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: A comparison of lake monitoring and modeling approaches - protecting freshwater resources in Lake Tahoe and Lake Taupo, and globally
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will compare water quality data and modeling research from Lake Tahoe (CA/NV, U.S.A.) to research on a New Zealand lake with similar water quality and which also has a modeling program, Lake Taupo. Dr. David Hamilton at the University of Waikato in New Zealand has considerable experience at Lake Taupo and is a leader in combining 3-D models with real-time sensor data. The PI?s current research focuses on monitoring and modeling water quality in the near-shore of Lake Tahoe. In collaborating with Dr. Hamilton and his graduate students, the PI will have access to data and models from Lake Taupo that are uniquely applicable to the his research on ecologically comparable Lake Tahoe; the PI will improve his approach to nearshore modeling, will collect reference data from New Zealand lakes, and will establish research links to eventually validate his western U.S. model on New Zealand lakes and globally. A robust and globally transferable nearshore water quality model will serve to better understand and protect the area of lakes and reservoirs on which human populations most directly depend.

The margins of lakes are both an important ecological habitat and the primary recreational and utilitarian usage point for humans. These near-shore areas are subject to high variability in water quality due to natural and anthropogenic inputs. Human development and changing climate patterns continue to force changes to these inputs. Understanding how these variations will affect near-shore water quality requires an understanding of the spatiotemporal response of near-shore areas to external loading, meteorology, and the geometric nature of a lake. The PI?s current research focuses on developing models of this response in Lake Tahoe. In collaborating with Dr. Hamilton, the PI will gain insight into generalizing his model for global application; he will learn new modeling approaches, collect reference data, and establish long-term research links to continually improve and apply his model to protect global freshwater reserves. This EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project compares water quality data and modeling research from Lake Tahoe (CA/NV, U.S.A.) to research on a New Zealand lake with similar characteristics, Lake Taupo. The margins of lakes serve as both important ecological habitat and the primary recreational and utilitarian usage point for humans. These near-shore areas are subject to high variability in water quality due to natural and anthropogenic inputs. Human development and changing climate patterns continue to force changes to these inputs. Understanding how these variations will affect near-shore water quality requires an understanding of the response, in space and time, of near-shore areas to external loading, meteorology, and the geometric nature of a lake. The goals of this project were: a) to gain insights into water quality analysis techniques from a leading research group in New Zealand; b) collect near-shore data from a New Zealand lake for comparison to data collected with the same technique from the nearshore of ecologically comparable Lake Tahoe; c) learn modelling techniques, and begin model development, for a comparative modelling study of Lake Taupo and Lake Tahoe. In meeting these objectives, the PI established baseline knowledge and initial data for performing comparative analyses of near-shore water quality processes in two global “great lakes.” This background will inform his advancement of global understanding of near-shore water quality in lakes.

 

The PI performed near-shore sampling of Lake Taupo as part of a study of nitrogen cycling in the Lake Taupo food web – a project run by a New Zealand PhD student. In supporting this project, the PI gained insight into unique sampling techniques and to ecological investigation methods.

The PI deployed a Turner Designs C3 fluorometer instrument at multiple sites in the nearshore of Lake Taupo to collect several days of high-frequency data for comparison to data collected in Lake Tahoe. Instrument deployments were designed to match deployments of similarly calibrated C3 fluorometers in Lake Tahoe; instruments recorded 30 sec averages of algae, organic matter, and turbidity data from bottom-anchored deployments at approximately 2 meter water depth. Recorded data were compared to Lake Tahoe data collected exactly six months prior (to account for northern versus southern hemisphere solar exposure), and using proper time offsets from UTC to match solar exposure (with consideration to daylight savings). While these data are insufficient to draw outright conclusions about the similarities and differences between oft-compared Lake Taupo and Lake Tahoe, they do provide base insight into similarities and differences between the systems. These basic data provide motivation for future modelling comparisons between the two lakes. Insights from modelling work on one lake could certainly prove insightful for modelling work on the other.

The PI also developed a three-dimensional hydrodynamic and ecological model of Lake Taupo. Representation of hydrodynamic and ecosystem-driven nitrogen concentration variability, in both space and time, will play an important roll in the  investigation of nutrient cycling in Lake Taupo. The PI performed initial model development work and generated output for model calibration. This work will form the basis of model runs for more recent years that will be used for comparison with nutrient data sampled as part of this study.

The objectives of this project were met. Knowledge gained and data collected during the PI’s exchange in New Zealand are informing, and will continue to inform, his PhD research, the underlying goal of which is to improve understanding of physical water quality processes to improve the management of one of the world’s most important natural resources – freshwater.
